Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Orgo lab techniques
Lab skills
Learned a lot about many common organic chemistry lab techniques.
So much reflux.
You learn common techniques for synthesizing and purifying organic products that parallel what you learn in lecture.
I was able to further develop my skills in a lab setting while also reinforcing the material that I learned in my Organic Chemistry lecture.
I learned how to synthesize and characterize various compounds.
This course goes more deeply into lab techniques learned in CHEM 222L, such as reflux, distillation, extraction, and recrystallization, as well as spectrometry (IR and 1H NMR).
Did learn organic lab techniques, common reaction mechanisms
I mastered basic lab skills that were developed in CHEM 222L such as reflux, distillation, separation, filtration, and analysis techniques such as melting point, TLC, and interpreting IR spectra.

A lot about chemical laboratory procedures and best practices. Relevant mechanism and organic chemistry concepts learned in the stand alone course were emphasized in this class. It was an all around very structured and easy to navigate course. A lot of insight was given into how one should best present their scientific findings such that the information is both concrete and succinct.
I honed my laboratory skills through this course, such as refining the techniques of refluxing, using a separatory funnel, and analyzing data through melt point analysis, TLC, etc.
I gained basic organic chemistry lab skills and better common sense in a chemistry laboratory.
I learned a lot about how different lab techniques work (NMR, IR spectroscopy, MP, TLC) and also about the different reaction conditions that facilitate the reactions we learn about in lecture!
Lab techniques.
Important lab safetly and experimental skills
I learned how to reflux and analyze NMR spectra.

A lot of cool techniques in lab chemistry. The second semester of lab doesn't teach as many new techniques as the first semester, but it's a good opportunity to practice becoming fluent with the apparatuses and to relate what's going on in lecture with what's being synthesized in the lab.
I learned how to fortify laboratory techniques such as conducting TLC, IR, vacuum filtration, recrystallization, reflux, and extraction.
How to employ organic chemistry techniques in synthesis

Orgo lab this semester did not teach me a ton more than last semester did. We did a lot of the same techniques; granted, the experiments this semester followed the topics we learned in class pretty closely, so it was cool to do, say, a Diels Alder reaction after learning about its mechanism. If nothing else, I now feel extra confident doing the lab techniques I learned and largely felt shaky on after first semester.

I improved my abilities to perform specific lab techniques, including reflux, vacuum filtration, IR spectrum analysis, TLC analysis, and melt point. We did more applicable experiments this semester, in terms of what kinds of reactions we would actually do in a lab.
Minimal new lab knowledge, only some experience with NMR and UV-Vis. Basically just reinforcing first-semester skills.
I was able to learn more about the techniques used in organic chemistry.
I got to practice various laboratory skills and procedures, and I learned a lot about safe lab practices such as proper waste disposal. I also got to practice some organic mechanisms.
Organic Chemistry Lab Skills.
Continued to improve on general organic chemistry lab techniques, including separation and synthesis methods.
Basic lab and analysis skills

CHEM 223L provided me with opportunities to practice concepts and techniques learned in CHEM 222L. I practiced synthesis of chemicals via reflux, melt point analysis, interpreting IR and NMR spectra, and carrying out TLC analysis. Before CHEM 223L, I was aware of these concepts and techniques (from CHEM 222L), but taking CHEM 223L solidified them very well. Also, I learned about the principles of Green Chemistry and why they are important in industry and academia.
I learned about NMR analysis and practiced many techniques from first semester lab, including vacuum filtration, recrystallization, IR analysis, TLC, etc.

This course is basically the same thing as the first semester: measure a powder, set up reflux, collect product, IR/MP/TLC. Every week. However, this semester you also cover NMR and some cooler reactions that go with the lecture. The products are also cooler! We did Tylenol, banana oil, and a seizure medication this semester which was a lot of fun.
This class taught and revised basic lab techniques which are very helpful for science related majors and research.
I learned how to reflux a lot. And how to work comfortably in a laboratory setting.
Organic chem lab techniques
The biggest thing that I developed was comfort and safety in carrying out chemical reactions and and organic chemistry protocols.

I have developed lab skills such as reflux, distillation, vacuum filtration, recrystallization. I have also learned about concepts such as TLC, IR spectroscopy, melt point, and NMR spectroscopy. I have also learned how to write lab reports and also read scientific papers.
I learned and honed my lab skills - especially reflux, TLC, vacuum filtration, and safety standards.
I gained valuable laboratory experience.

A continuation of Lab 1, there were many more synthesis reactions which were pretty fun, especially when students got to make Dilantin and Acetmainophen, making the chemistry more applicable to chemistry in the outside world

You'll learn a lot about the application of organic chemistry (how to implement syntheses in real life, how to think about chemistry experimentally, etc.) in a stress-free environment (the grading's a bit variable since it's based on the TA, but I've found that for the most part, it's pretty fair and lenient). The class helps you learn to be more detail-oriented and  process-oriented, and overall, was very well-organized to help students learn.

I learned how to conduct full synthesis experiments independently and work on my own.
I liked how I became more self-reliant in the second semester of orgo lab.

This class is helpful in teaching the skill required to perform organic reactions and how to purify and analyze the products. The class also reinforces some of the topics from organic chemistry lecture class.
I learned how to confidently conduct a lab experiment on my own.
Learned how to do reflux, vacuum filtration, recrystallization, and a bunch of product analysis techniques.
A sense of self
Lot of techniques important to working in a Chem lab.
I learned how to interpret NMR, how to characterize products by melt point, IR, and TLC. I learned about different organic reactions and  about the principles of Green Chemistry.
Very useful organic lab techniques and an appreciate for synthesis experiments/reactions.
I learned a lot about how to reflux and about several mechanisms for chemical reactions. I also learned about the importance of precision.
Reviewed a lot of the techniques from last semester. Also learned how to interpret NMR Spectra.
Organic lab techniques.
good continuation of orgo 1! standard lab class
How to reflux, recrystallize, and characterize products using TLC, melting point, and IR analysis x10
I was able to apply and practice the techniques I learned last semester in lab.
Syntheses of various compounds and purification and analysis methods.
I learned about organic chemistry lab techniques such as synthesis, extraction, and purification.
You learned a lot about lab skills but definitely not as much as in first semester. It was very repetitive and more just a rehashing of the techniques you learned in Orgo Lab I.
I learned how to facilitate organic chemistry reactions and operate advanced chemistry equipment.
I gained some basic organic chemistry lab skills and became more aware of green chemistry principles.
Orgo Lab II focused a lot on applications of skills learned in Orgo I. Lots of synthesis and data analysis.
I learned laboratory techniques of the synthesis of various compounds.
I learned how to work safely and efficiently in a chemical lab setting
I learned lab and safety skills as well as data analysis skills such as IR and TLC analysis.
I built upon the lab skills I learned last semester and developed new skills as well. I became confident in my ability to properly perform lab techniques and saw improvements in my syntheses.
Developed general lab skills
Necessary skills for organic chemstiry lab

I learned about different o chem reaction mechanisms from a practical perspective. I developed a good understanding of safety principles and sustainability principles which I can use to guide my scientific thinking and design process in the future. I feel like I mastered important techniques like reflux, recrystallization, TLC, IR, and MP not only from the execution perspective but also the analysis. I've learned how to troubleshoot an experiment and to identify why certain things happen during its course so I can fix it appropriately. Also developed a stronger scientific writing ability.
I learned and applied a lot of synthetic techniques to create really cool and interesting organic compounds.
Reflux, crystallization, filtration. Really, really well.
Application of skills developed in lecture and last semester organic chemistry lab.
A lot about organic chemistry lab techniques (NMR, extraction, tons of reflux).
I learned so many important organic chemistry techniques!
How to prepare for lab and translate book knowledge to bench knowledge.
continued learning lab techniques (continued from 222L), learned NMR and IR, more lab reports
Laboratory chemistry skills like TLC analysis, how to operate lab equipment like the melt point machine

I improved on the lab techniques that I developed during the first semester of organic chemistry lab. I improved on techniques such as recrystallization, IR, TLC, and melt point. I also improved my scientific writing through doing post lab assignments and learned NMR.
This class taught me a great deal about lab work while also improving my overall laboratory efficiency.
I learned more about standard laboratory procedure and learned the principles of NMR and how to apply them to generate and recognize spectra of specific compounds.

This lab class really taught me how to be efficient. If I prepared for the experiment ahead of time, it would go smoothly and lab became fun instead of a drag. Lots of the experiments were synthesizing compounds, which was pretty cool. This course also teaches you how to assess the purity of a compound through different ways, like melting point, FTIR, NMR, and TLC. I became very "good with my hands" in setting up experiments and having more insight into why certain reagents were added, instead of just adding them. For a lab class, it was well run, and complemented the Orgo II lecture well. This course also taught me how to write a professional lab report using the Scientific Writing Guide.
We leaned about fundamental techniques in organic chemistry and put them to practice in different experiments throughout the semester.

Organic chemistry lab technique
Academic writing format/technique
Chemical properties/safety
Green chemistry principles
Chemical product analysis
This course helped me develop the technical and practical thinking skills necessary for further laboratory experience in organic chemistry.
Pretty basic organic chemistry lab, we went over different lab skills and synthesis pathways
I gained further knowledge of how to properly and safely work in an organic chemistry lab. I became more confident working with chemicals and conducting experiments.

This lab course allowed me to continue to improve my skills in an organic chemistry lab. We learned most of the necessary skills first semester and this second semester allowed us to improve those skills and to apply them to organic chemistry principles.
I built on skills I learned in the first semester and enjoyed the synthesis of various compounds.

I learned and developed a lot of new lab techniques for synthesizing compounds, safely disposing of dangerous chemicals, and applying Green Chemistry principles. I also was able to see a lot of the reactions we learned in lecture happen in the test tube.
I don't feel like I learned much at all in this course.
Organic chemistry lab techniques, organic chemistry reactions
A deeper understanding of the process of organic chemical synthesis and a firmer grasp on laboratory techniques.
continuation of orgo II with more techniques
I think a lab practical exam would be better than a multiple choice exam
Pretty good. Parts of the EP and PLA/PLB seemed like a waste of time.

It is a very good lab course. The labs are interesting, but can be a little repetitive. I wish we had covered NMR sooner and had more experience with it so that, going into the final, we were more comfortable with it.
The course was very reasonable and well organized overall, so not many suggestions.
Christine DiMeglio should run every lab at Yale! Every assignment taught me something useful and all of the syntheses were of interesting chemicals and used green processes

This course is great because applying the reactions that you learn in lecture really assists sinfully understanding them mechanistically. Also the more hands off approach of the instructors helped me in my problem solving as I had to be able to find solutions if I made mistakes, but also knew that I would have assistance if I needed it.
Course structured very well.
The experiments show lab applications of several reactions covered by the Organic Chemistry lecture, so students can understand the material much better.

Some of the writing/reports was really tedious and just wasted time. Grading was also arbitrary, especially in post-labs: points taken off for not answering questions that weren't even asked. Actual lab time was a good experience.

I think this course can be improved by giving it a little more relevance. While I enjoyed synthesizing materials, by the end of it, I still didn't really understand why we were doing it. I think better explaining the relevance of such experiments would improve the class.

Strength: Predictability--every week is the same even if the lab exercise might change. Do the EP, do the readings and do the lab. 

Weakness: None I can think of!
This course is structured very well - the assignments are well-spaced and require work, but not too much, and the experiments in lab are both educational and fun! I would not change anything.

I loved the labs and the atmosphere as well as the level of work. I wish some of the labs would have more concrete outputs; for example, creating luminol could be fun! Making a banana fragrance and making Tylenol were both great labs.

I think this course is by far the best lab course at Yale. It is very straightforward, and this allowed me to learn more, because new ideas were introduced with a consistent format and framework. Not having quizzes etc. meant it wasn't stressful, but the EPs still forced you to understand what was going on before getting to lab. Some aspects of the work outside of class were kind of stressful  for example, some of the prompts were very vague but required super specific responses, and some of the questions on the final exam really did not make sense given what we learned in lab + the course packet. Still, this was by far the best/least stressful lab course I've taken at Yale.

The labs become painfully boring after 4 or 5. The vast majority consist of letting a reflux sit for 30-75 minutes, then running TLC, IR, and meltpoint analysis, then being happy you get to go home early. The prelab preparation is marginally more engaging, if only because you have to think about the mechanisms a little bit more, which are what actually change from experiment to experiment. The TLC, IR, and mp analysis are all essentially the same as what is covered in the first semester lab. I'm genuinely unclear on how to fix this, but maybe using NMR earlier in the semester to change things up a bit would help, or taking the time to explicitly go through mechanisms and why they happen the way they do.

Dr DiMeglio wrote up some really neat labs and a really helpful lab manual for this course. However, I felt that I didn't learn that many new lab techniques, and at a certain point we were just doing syntheses under reflux for every day of the lab. I would have liked more practice with NMR and different types of data analysis (besides TLC and IR).

Dr. DiMeglio is very clear about expectations for the course, responds quickly and fairly to student concerns, and her course manual is incredibly comprehensive. She puts learning first and makes it fun. It's always a pleasure when she comes over to speak with us in lab, making sure we're understanding the point of the experiments and engaging with us. Assignments are very reasonable, and I felt like the questions on the post-labs facilitated us processing the important concepts.
Love DiMeglio, but very varying quality of TAs.

One strength is conducting syntheses that involve the utilization of familiar lab techniques. Most of the syntheses involved reflux and recrystallization, which particularly allowed students to improve their technique in these areas, which is something I appreciated. It was also amazing to synthesize vital pharmaceuticals, namely Dilantin, in this course.
The course was great, although it was a bit repetitive

For a lab, this course was very forgiving. The workload was very manageable, and being in lab itself was not so stressful because we were never hugely pressed for time, which was a strength. There were also a few dead weeks built into the semester for written assignments instead of lab work, which provided a much needed break. There were no glaring weaknesses.

One of the strengths of this course is that we really reinforced a lot of common lab techniques with each experiment; if I were put into a lab and asked to perform one of the techniques we learned this semester, I would feel very comfortable with doing that technique because many of them were part of each experiment we did throughout the semester. One of the weaknesses is that almost every experiment was a variation of the same procedure, so we didn't learn any new techniques and I often didn't feel very engaged while doing the preparation before lab or even during lab because I was so used to what we were doing. However, I think this course is very well supported by Dr. DiMeglio and the Teaching Fellows, and they are very accessible whenever anyone has a question, in or out of the lab. This semester was also very interesting, and many of the labs were fun to do and to see what would happen!

Strengths: Well-organized, manageable workload, good mix of practical and theoretical understanding
Weaknesses: Sometimes monotonous

I felt that this course was good in giving an introduction to what lab work is like, but we don't do much critical thinking during the labs. We learn some stuff through our experiments, but you don't need to know anything to actually get through the labs. You do need knowledge for the final though, which is kind of interesting.

The labs are generally interesting, and the assignments are manageable. I did feel that the labs could sometimes get repetitive and that we would do similar procedures multiple times, but for the most part I felt engaged. I liked that the lab was hands-on and usually individual.
All depends on the TA you get.

This course was very nicely organized and probably the best an intro organic chem lab course could be taught. A lot of the work (like the weekly EPs) felt a bit useless. The grading rubrics seem to emphasize format more than content, which is often frustrating. Overall, Dr. DiMeglio is a wonderful instructor.
Well organized, engaging, relaxed learning environment
I think that this course is very well structured and well taught. I dont really have any negative things to say about it. I had a lot of fun!

This course could be improved by either adding more new techniques to be covered or having more focused practice of new techniques. The labs in this course were mostly using techniques that we had covered in the first semester but there was little opportunity or encouragement to refine them. We were able to practice the techniques but without guidance on how they could be done more efficiently or effectively. The only real feedback we got was our percent yield, which was complicated by too many factors to be informative on the success of any particular technique. I personally did not like preparing the chemical tables for several labs at once. While this used a lab day effectively, it made boring work even worse by piling all together, making mistakes more likely. I am glad that we covered NMR, as it is a crucial technique for identifying organic compounds.

Strengths: the instructor. Dr. D is one of the kindest, intelligent, most helpful and caring professors that I have ever had. She genuinely cares about her students and really encourages us to learn (basically she is the antithesis of Dr. G; she is the angel and Dr. G is the devil, etc.). I like how she designs the labs and generally her attitude about lab class at Yale.

Weaknesses: the TAs. Your grade is solely dependent on how strict your TA is and how helpful/engaged they are in the lab. Because of this, the course is significantly easier for some students and significantly harder for others. I wish that there was more standardization on what the TAs were expected to do.
The strength of this course is that the experiments were interesting and far more useful than titrations.  Also, most weeks, the lab does not require 4 hours.
I very much enjoyed this course!
You learn how to do lab techniques but its repetitive, you end up doing the same things every lab
I think that the weakest part of the course is that it isn't always lined up with the lecture, so we are doing things in lab that we haven't learned about in lecture.

This was the first lab I've ever taken at Yale that I didn't feel was a hostile environment. Coming from Prof Ganapathi's lab had all but dissuaded me from hard sciences in it's entirety, but the clear focus in this lab on mentorship and learning has made all the difference. I'm thankful for this lab for redeeming the fun, joy, and worth of hard science learning for me.

Strengths is that the labs are laid out very nicely. You know what you need to know and also the course packet provides all the information you need. A weakness of the class is that the tests and quizzes are pretty tricky and it was hard to prepare for them.
The class was very well structured and organized.

Interesting material! Great professor (Dr. DiMgelio is the sweetest person), and I had a great TA.  Weaknesses would be that sometimes emails were a little hairy because they would be really long with course announcements and I am guilty of sometimes skimming them too quickly

The class was super well-organized--students knew exactly when assignments were due, TAs were responsive to students needs, and Dr. DiMeglio was a joy to have in class. My TA did a great job of giving a short synopsis of the chemical concepts we would implement in lab at the start of each lab day, and I occasionally found those summaries to be pertinent and helpful in explaining ideas introduced in the corresponding lecture course. In all honesty, there weren't that many weaknesses, except maybe for the fact that grading could be a little variable among the TAs: it was a great, well-executed course.
The course is perfectly set up to allow students to grow as scientists and more importantly learn from their mistakes.
Strengths: well organized, reinforces concepts from lecture
All in all i think its as good as it can get, very thoughtfully done. I very appreciate getting out before 5 and being taught independence.
I think the course is fine as it is. Maybe the final should be more based on a practical instead of a multiple choice test.
A strength is that each lab was clearly thought out and directions were clear. I was never confused about why we were learning what we were learning.

Strengths: Very organized, engaging, content is awesome. 
Weaknesses: Very few
A strength is I feel very comfortable with reflux and following a procedure to get to my desired product. A weakness is we only really focused on reflux.
It was a bit too repetitive. We did reflux almost every single week, then vaccuum filtration, then product analysis.
Great course
typical orgo lab class taken a a prereq, class had a good atmosphere and great teaching team
The professor and TAs very nice, but the course itself is not very exciting. The course did reinforce both theoretical and experimental organic chemistry concepts though.

A strength of this course is the small sections that we are divided into. Also, Dr. DiMeglio always checks in with everyone during lab, which makes all the students feel like they are cared about. A weakness of this course is that it depends almost entirely on the teaching fellows; some teaching fellows encourage learning and offer support more than others.

I think the TA's and the Dr. DiMeglio are definitely strengths of this course. They were always willing to help and made sure we were well prepared for lab each week.  Also the way the course is set up is very easy to follow.

It was really repetitive, and every week was just a reflux and the same 4 types of data collection. Also, I think the focus on formatting is annoying and should be graded on less harshly. It seems to be the main factor that brings people's grades down which seems less important in a chemistry lab course.
strengths: well organized. Course packet is informative.
The course was good for becoming more independent and knowledgeable in lab, though I found the grading of Post-Labs to be a bit cryptic and stressful.

The procedures became very similar week to week. I felt confident I could do them, but didnt feel like I was learning that much new. I like the structure of the course, though its a little frustrating how much of the grade is weighted towards the final.

Strengths: This course is well planned! During lab, DiMeglio always makes an effort to walk around and give us great advice on improving our lab techniques. She makes orgo lab very enjoyable!

Weakness: None

This course overall is really good. I think it has a great balance of workload and assignment types. I think the course could be improved by incorporating a larger number of experimental techniques. It felt like we really only did reflux all semester, and it would have been nice to mix it up a little bit.
A strength was being able to work with partners on some labs because it allowed us to share strategies and tips. A weakness was sometimes having to wait to use equipment like IR.

The course was very well-organized (a vast improvement from the general chemistry labs). I felt like I was learning a lot but never felt overwhelmed. If something went wrong in an experiment, we were trained on how to safely deal with the problem, and TAs and staff members were always available to help.

Strengths: I loved how hands on everything is. If help is ever needed it's always right there because sections are small and the professors are constantly roaming the lab.

Weaknesses: Every lab felt the same this semester. Mix stuff in a round bottom flask, heat at reflux, collect, purify, and analyze. It was very repetitive.
Well organizes. TA's not super helpful

The course helps students develop laboratory skills and practice techniques for conducting important chemical reactions. It also helps students learn how to write clearly, concisely, and effectively in scientific writing. We learn about safety and learn how to operate in the lab to optimize safety, sustainability, and productivity.

I think there is a large degree of repetitiveness in the course. The middle 5 or so experiments largely all follow the same pattern of: prep materials, reflux, purify (through recrystallization or something) and characterize with TLC / IR / MP. This makes it easy for the student to get away with not understanding the actual mechanism or reaction at hand since the only thing they need to focus on is conducting the reaction and yielding product, which becomes second nature after so much practice. I think varying the purification methods would be helpful in learning more techniques and making lab less repetitive. I also think it would be nice to have a tour of actual chemistry labs so we can learn what kinds of tools and techniques our professors and TAs use in real life. We could write a report or a response on this.

The strength of this course is that the labs we did were really interesting and DiMeglio is wonderful. The weakness in this course is the way that it is graded. The grading is insanely nitpicky, and, depending on your TA, your grade could widely differ. The majority of the grade again falls on the final and the PLs, and the PLs are super subjectively graded by different TAs. The final required an intense amount of studying in order to do well. The grading made the course very stressful because, otherwise, the course was very interesting.

Chill course, but overly repetitive. The second semester of Orgo Lab only repeats techniques that they learned in the first semester without exploring more techniques and teaching something new (yes, NMR is an important exception to this). Teach something new, please! The products, esp. toward the end, are neat, but the course as a whole could be diversified.

Strength: direct application of theory learned in class. Interesting and enjoyable to perform syntheses.

Weakness: very similar to first semester - very few new skills required
Very very interesting course with extremely supportive staff!
The class is great! Well structured! Experiments are really great for learning techniques and important reactions but not too long or boring!

The strength of this course is that if follows along with the lecture pretty well (better than first semester) but it could do an even better job! When it does supplement the lecture course, I learn the topics considerably better. One weakness is that assignments are oddly weighted. The grade on each assignment rarely reflects the amount of work on the assignment, and it would be nice if it did.

Strengths: well organized, good length if experiments, interesting variety of techniques and experiments
Weaknesses: could use more transparency with what reports and lab notes are specifically graded on
Strengths: well planned labs that are relatively short in prepared ahead of time, reasonable post lab assignments and final. Weaknesses: grading inconsistencies across TAs.

The strength of this course is how reasonable it is. It was always clear what was expected, which made preparation for each lab straightforward. The only improvement I would suggest is removing some of the more repetitive aspects of the course such as requiring the procedure in each lab notes.
There was very little I learned in this course that I did not already learn in 222L.  I feel like this course exists only because it needs to, but it is largely a waste of time.

Strengths:
1) Lab is short, doesn't take the full 4 hours
2) Only 2 lab reports per semester
3) Well organized, although there are many grammatical errors in the lab manual
4) The EPs are helpful in preparing for lab

Weaknesses:
1) The final is an unfair representation of the course. I found the course to be very skills-based and practical, which I loved, but the final was 35 multiple choice questions that were confusing and poorly worded, and I don't see how a 1 hour exam reflects the skills learned in a lab course. I would prefer a practical final.
2) Discrepancy in grading among TAs. Not sure how you could change this, but some TAs definitely graded more harshly than others on the EPs and post-lab reports.

The TAs and Dr. Dimeglio deserve alot of praise for making this a successful course. There is alot of demand from premed students, and the instruction team makes the course accessible to these students by making labs that relate to medicine or pharmacy. They are great at answering questions and are very approachable.

Strengths: amazingly engaged director, kind TA's, clean/organized environment, fun 'classroom' atmosphere
Weaknesses: none

By far, the greatest strength of this course is the supportive, welcoming, and exciting environment that Dr. DiMeglio, her lab staff Teresa and Elisa, and the teaching fellows go out of their way to create in the laboratory. I will elaborate on some of this information in the instructor and teaching fellow evaluations, but starting with Dr. DiMeglio, her passion for helping students learn practical organic chemistry skills is vibrant, pervasive, and tireless. She goes above and beyond to create an environment in lab that is conducive to student learning and engagement, and I have found that myself and all of my peers are able to focus more on learning than fear of mistakes as a result. Dr. DiMeglio and her staff do not create this environment at the expense of high standards, however; students are often reminded or corrected about how to improve their techniques, but the comments are always constructive, meant to guide and cultivate student learning. Especially as a first-year who occasionally has felt lost with the year of transition, I have found this environment to be extremely important and encouraging in my desire to pursue a career in science. Though I am surely biased, of all my friends ranging from first-years to seniors who are enrolled in or have been enrolled in a variety of laboratory courses, I have on average heard the most positive feedback and enthusiasm for Chem 222L/223L than any other laboratory course. Granted, I realize that not all laboratory courses can be compared next to one another, but I do think that the pro-curiosity environment that Dr. DiMeglio should be recognized as an exemplary model of how to encourage future scientists.

One potential weakness of this course is that second semester (223L) we seem to do a lot of similar syntheses. I don't know how big of a weakness this is since synthesis is obviously incredible important in organic chemistry and it's important to not only learn it, but for the procedures to almost become second nature, but I do think there was room for learning other techniques if the instructors want to squeeze something else in. Maybe spending longer on NMR or introducing it earlier before the one NMR day at the end of the semester could be considered. But then again it was very effective as is, so doesn't necessarily need to be changed.

I think the course is really well organized with the different labs and reports. They follow the format of organic chemistry II pretty closely so it's usually easy to follow along with the theory of the course.

The strengths of this course are how involved Dr. DiMeglio was with this course. Every lab, she would walk around and talk to each individual person and ask them if they had any questions with the lab. She was also very available and happy to meet with you outside of lab. The weaknesses are that the TAs do not always grade the same way and some seem harsher than others.
The course teaches students a lot of skills and it is very informative. Honestly, I don't think anything can really be changed. Improvement isn't needed.

The course is clearly organized and adjusted so to fit the schedule of students, which I greatly appreciated. However, the final exam is difficult because it requires us to suddenly learn all of the theory of the experiments which was barely discussed throughout the course. Improvements could include changing the structure to more fully analyze the theory or having the final be more of a lab practical.

It gave a lot of independence to each student to manage their time wisely and be responsible for their procedure. However, perhaps one weakness is we didn't really go over any exam questions/review material for the exam at all. All studying was done entirely on our own.

Strengths: I love Prof DiMeglio and how she gets to know all the students and consistently checks in on us.  It is the highlight of Orgo 2

Weaknesses: large focus on procedural knowledge that feels irrelevant.  Repetitive analysis of TLC and MP every time does not add to my knowledge or experience.  In fact, nearly all of the procedures are quite repetitive and the labs seem to have no focus.

This course was really great. The lab that we do were fun and informative, and I sometimes even looked forward to getting to go in and work. I do feel that the exam was a bit too challenging, or the course was not demanding enough through the semester to help students properly obtain the information necessary for the final.

Strengths: very chill until the final exam, Dr. DiMeglio is kind and so helpful
Weakness: the final exam is multiple choice based and about 35 questions, so getting a couple of questions wrong could tank your final grade.

Extremely well run course, especially for such a large lab class. Structure of the pre- and post-lab work was great, and experiments were worthwhile without being monotonous. The only criticism I have is that much of the grading was done by the TA's, and was therefore inconsistent across lab groups.
this was a great class-- very well taught.  i liked the changes made from orgo I to orgo II lab, specifically the SDS pages frontloaded.
Yes!  Great lab
Yes.
It is a very good lab course. I highly recommend it to other students in STEM.
Yes! It wasn't very difficult, and the labs weren't stressful, but I still I learned a lot and have become much more conformable with lab techniques.
YES CHRISTINE DIMEGLIO IS SO SO SO AWESOME!
I would not recommend this course to another student simply because it is time consuming and because you have to take another class concurrently or prior to taking this course.
Yes. It was a very enjoyable lab.
I would definitely recommend this course to any student who is interested in Organic Chemistry and wants to learn more about basic lab techniques.
No, you're probably taking it for some kind of requirement.
I think it's a pretty good class. I would definitely take it if you're taking second semester orgo, but can't really justify that with anything.
If you must, you must. But it is pretty good.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who needs a lab credit - it is much more fun and manageable than gen chem lab.
Absolutely! It's a great way to learn organic chemistry lab skills.

I wouldn't necessarily ever recommend taking a lab course for fun, but if you had to, this would be a good option. It's really not very stressful but you get to learn techniques (NMR, spectroscopy etc.) and you get to think about orgo beyond the textbook descriptions.

The labs become painfully boring after 4 or 5. The vast majority consist of letting a reflux sit for 30-75 minutes, then running TLC, IR, and meltpoint analysis, then being happy you get to go home early. The prelab preparation is marginally more engaging, if only because you have to think about the mechanisms a little bit more, which are what actually change from experiment to experiment. The TLC, IR, and mp analysis are all essentially the same as what is covered in the first semester lab. I'm genuinely unclear on how to fix this, but maybe using NMR earlier in the semester to change things up a bit would help, or taking the time to explicitly go through mechanisms and why they happen the way they do.
The course is probably required for a lot of students, but nonetheless this class was really fun.

Orgo lab with Dr. DiMeglio is the best part of STEM/pre-med requirements! It is a reasonable workload, has clear expectations, and Dr. DiMeglio is available and involved, so even if you don't have a great TA, you'll be okay.
Yes, I would recommend this course. Orgo lab remains the best lab I have taken at Yale. It was perfectly suited for students, like myself, that did not take the lecture and lab in tandem.
The class was great, but really only if you plan to go into biology or chemistry research
You're probably taking this course because you need to, but it's really not that bad. Labs in general are somewhat arduous, but this one is pretty chill and not that time-intensive.
Yup! Orgo lab is much more enjoyable than gen chem lab. Grading can be tricky, but the overall experience is relatively painless.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student because it is a good way to learn common lab techniques that can be used in any chemistry lab in the future. It's also a nice course to have alongside very challenging courses because it can provide a nice break from the intensity that often accompanies Yale courses. If you're interested in chemistry and in learning applicable lab techniques, I would recommend this course for you!
Not many new skills gained beyond the first semester. Only take second semester if needed for requirements.
Yes
I would if you want an introduction to organic chemistry lab, but you mostly learn about techniques rather than lab thought process and stuff.
I would recommend this course to anyone who needs a chemistry lab of some sort for whatever reason. The labs themselves are interesting, Dr. DiMeglio does a great job, and the workload is manageable.
If you need it.

If you have worked this far, take CHEM 223L! Its even more fun than CHEM 222L because you get to make chemicals and test them. There is a lot of freedom and the experiments are not stressful at all; its basically the polar opposite of general chemistry lab. Youll have fun and youll solidify your organic chemistry knowledge in CHEM 223L. Take it!
While the course could be better, I would still recommend it. It was still helpful to have an opportunity to practice techniques from first semester even if feedback was not offered.

Again, if you're reading this, you probably have to take this course and will not get a choice. However, I would look forward to this. If you're coming off of the first semester of orgo lab, this course is literally the exact same thing and so you will get a very similar experience all the way through.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in science to get good lab experience.

I love that organic lab is so low-stress. Your day-to-day grades make up so little of your final grade, so you can really just focus on the experiment instead of feeling anxious about everything you do which is fantastic.
I would! If you are premed and/or interested in chemistry, it is a great class.
Yes, but the final exam will make or break your grade. Each question is 5 points, I believe
Absolutely, Dr. Dimeglio does her absolute best to work with students at every knowledge level.
Yes, I would recommend this class to another student. You learn important organic chemistry skills and concepts, but in a low-stress, fun environment.
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student.

I would! I took it because I needed it for my major but for others that are looking for lab experience and want a super nice and enthusiastic professor, it would be great to take it! But if youre not so much into that idea, then you should take something else. The work is standard and doable and you can always ask for help

Yes--most students in this class are required to take it, but even as someone who's not terribly interested in organic chemistry, I though the class was enjoyable. From what I've heard, it's certainly less stressful than general chemistry lab, and for a class that only met once a week, the intellectual payoff was sizable.
Yes
The second semester of orgo lab is doable and even kind of fun!

I would recommend this course. Christine DiMeglio is a wonderful lab professor and she genuinely cares for her students. Though the class is more challenging in terms of the experiments, I found it rewarding to be able to synthesize a product within the time that we had every week.
Yeah. The course is a great way to put chemistry knowledge learned in class in practice.
Yes. This is a great lab.
Yes, it is not very time consuming. Also you get very confident performing basic organic chemistry lab techniques.
Its a good time!
Yes, it's a good fundamentals course.
Yes! Organic chemistry lab is really engaging!
100% if interested in chemistry, or if a pre-med.
I would recommend this course. It is a basic lab but synthesizing things is fun and Professor DiMeglio is an angel. Definitely an ok pre-med requirement.
Yes, it is a great environment and has great teachers and TAs to help facilitate learning.

if you're taking it it's as a prereq
great TA/ prof though and nice lab atmosphere
Yes, it's probably mandatory if you're considering it, and it's not a pain at all (it's certainly a lot better than gen chem lab)

Yes, it isn't a lot of work but is a lot of fun. In addition, I felt like I became more secure on the techniques I learned last semester because of the amount of practice I had in applying them to different experiments this semester.
Much chilled than gen chem lab and you actually learn
Yes, highly recommend! It's a great laboratory course and is a good continuation of 1st semester organic chemistry lab.
Yes. I would definitely recommend this course because you learn a lot under really great instruction.
Yes. it teaches very valuable lab skills.
Dr. DiMeglio is a joy! Likely you have to take this class for major or pre-professional program, so you don't have much choice. But this one is one of the better ones!
Its really not that bad!! Kinda fun, almost!
Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to other students. DiMeglio makes Orgo lab very enjoyable and I felt that I improved my lab technique after this course.
Totally! For most people, they dont have a choice in taking this lab, but it still is a class I would recommended. I think it is a really well designed lab
I would recommend this course. It strengthened my knowledge of organic chemistry and helped me understand how reactions are performed in practice.

Yes, if you are interested in learning organic chemistry lab techniques, this is the perfect second component to the introductory lab courses. By the end you will gain a lot of confidence in performing different techniques and understanding why you do each step.
Yes. The skills learned are extremely helpful in the long run as well as being a very enjoyable experience.
Yes, It is instructive

Yes, I would recommend this course. As long as Dr. Di Meglio is teaching and you have a dedicated TA, you're in good hands. Probably required for most people who take the course anyway (pre-meds, chem/E majors, etc).
A much better lab class than gen chem with work that is actually equivalent to a 0.5 credit course

I would recommend this course if they have to take it or are interested in organic chemistry. The only downside again is the grading because the assignments are super specific with many points going towards formatting, precise keywords, etc. that felt largely arbitrary. DiMeglio is amazing however!
Yes, it goes along relatively well with the lecture course. It's a really laid-back course in comparison to Gen. Chem, but nothing super special. Relatively repetitive in terms of procedures.
Yes! A fun time to learn and do chemistry.
YES it's so much fun and such a relief to actually enjoy lab compared to gen chem lab!!
Yes I would! It's not going to be your favorite class, but it's probably one of the better intro lab courses at Yale!
if you're in this course, you're probably taking this for pre-med or your major. Lab's are pretty repetitive, but I wouldn't say it's a bad course.
I would recommend this course. It is well organized, has a reasonable workload, and Dr. DiMeglio is great!

I would recommend this course to another student. The material is pretty easy to grasp, and the workload is light. The teaching team does a great job of teaching the material, and questions are always quickly answered. Also, the class does a great job of improving one's efficiency in the lab: a skill I found useful in my own research as well.
Absolutely.  This course is well-organized and well-taught.  Students receive immediate and constant feedback and support from very knowledgeable TA's.

Yes, I loved Organic Chemistry Lab. It was efficient and interesting. Most people who take it are pre-med and need the requirement, but it's a great class. I hope you like your TA, though, because you work with them a lot.
I took this as a premed requirement, as many students will. This is a necessary course for many students, but at least it is not a bad one.

Yes, but only for chemistry/biology majors. This course provides an in-depth understanding of chemical lab techniques. It is a skill primarily used in the chemistry and pre-med communities. The director and TA's are incredibly engaged, which inspires the students to learn and work hard. The effort one puts in (studying, following directions, etc.) seems to actually produce results, unlike in other courses
Yes. See previous comment on strengths and weaknesses.
It's one of those classes you have to take, but it's not that bad.
I would recommend this course to another student because Dr. DiMeglio is great and makes lab a much better experience than gen chem lab.

Yes but only if it is necessary for them or if they are interested in the subject. Though the course is great, spending 4 hours in one class even if it is only once a week can become time consuming if you have a super busy schedule.
This course is a very engaging and interesting lab, especially when taken with a fun TA and friends.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. It's a fair amount of work, and it's challenging but at a level that is manageable and still interesting. The class is very well organized by the course manual, and you are always given warning far in advance about assignments and what is expected.
You're probably only taking this course if you're required to, since it's neither interesting nor easy.
If you're premed/MCDB, then you have to take this class. But it's a good way to consolidate what you learn from orgo lecture
Yes, extremely well-run and worthwhile lab course if you're interested in organic chemistry.
Yes, Orgo lab is really fun and not too much work.  The professor wants students to learn and is great at answering questions!
